fields.label: 5G readiness
fields.definition: The amount of spectrum assigned and ready for 5G use within the so-called 5G pioneer bands. These bands are 700 MHz (703-733 MHz and 758-788 MHz), 3.6 GHz (3400-3800 MHz) and 26 GHz (1000 MHz within 24250-27500 MHz). All three spectrum bands have an equal weight.

fields.label: IPv6 readiness - websites having a AAAA coverage in DNS records (as % of most visited websites)
fields.alt_label: IPv6 readiness of most visited websites
fields.definition: IPv6 ready websites are those having at least one AAAA in their DNS records (means the website is visible/can reply to users having an IPv6 connectivity). Tests are done every trimester through a script run by the IPv6 Observatory study on the 1 million most visited websites list provided by Alexa. Websites are attributed to countries on the basis of their main operation location as provided by MaxMind GeoIP database.

fields.label: Actual download speed of fixed broadband subscriptions
fields.definition: Average Download Speed during peak periods (ACTSPEED), measured with a specially configured hardware device (SamKnows Whitebox), which runs a series of purpose-built tests to measure various aspect of Internet performance. The measured speed refers to a sample of subscriptions using a similar technology offered by internet service providers. Offers are not weigthed with market shares, so the measured speed cannot be interpreted as the average experienced by consumers.

fields.label: Affordability of standalone Fixed Internet Access (minimum price offer)
fields.definition: Affordability is defined as 12 times the monthly price divided by the "real adjusted gross disposable income of households per capita" of the previous year. Disposable income data come from Eurostat table tec00113. Monthly price of standalone Fixed Broadband Internet Access offers, include value added tax, exclude the additional cost of telephony or cable line (if any), and refers to the minimum price in the group of similar subscriptions offered by internet service providers (see the original indicator).

fields.label: Average time to grant
fields.definition:
The Time to Grant (TTG) is defined as the time lapsed from a call's closing date (deadline for submission of proposals) to that of a grant signature by the European Commission. In the case of two-stage calls for proposals, it is the second stage call deadline that is used in the calculation of the Time to Grant. Time to grant is expressed in calendar days. 
Average time to grant is the arythmetic average for all grants within the defined scope.

fields.label: DSL subscriptions share in fixed broadband
fields.alt_label: DSL subscriptions share in fixed broadband
fields.definition: Share of DSL (Digital Subscriber Line) in total fixed broadband subscriptions.

fields.label: Fixed broadband coverage (2005-2010)
fields.definition: Coverage is a supply indicator, defined as the percentage of total/rural population living in areas served by fixed broadband: either DSL or cable modem networks.
fields.note: Indicator collected until 2010. Then replaced with two different coverage indicators, for standard broadband and NGA respectively.

fields.label: Fibre to the Premises coverage/availability (as a % of households)
fields.definition: Coverage is a supply indicator defined as the percentage of Households living in areas served by FTTP

fields.label: Herfindahl index on broadband competition
fields.definition: Herfindahl index calculated for seven different connection technologies: xDSL, full or shared LLU, Cable, FTTH, FTTB, Other NGA, Other. Their respective market shares are expressed in percentage of all fixed broadband subscriptions. A small index indicates a competitive industry with no dominant technological platform. The index values raises with concentration over one or few platforms.

fields.label: Fixed broadband subscriptions
fields.definition: Number of fixed broadband subscriptions (lines).

fields.label: New entrants' share in fixed broadband subscriptions
fields.alt_label: New entrants' share in fixed broadband subscriptions
fields.definition: Market share based on fixed broadband subscriptions (lines). New entrants mean operators that did not enjoy special and exclusive rights or de facto monopoly for the provision of voice telephony services before the liberalisation.

fields.label: NGA broadband coverage/availability (as a % of households)
fields.definition: Coverage is a supply indicator defined as the percentage of Households living in areas served by NGA. Next Generation Access includes the following technologies: FTTH, FTTB, Cable Docsis 3.0, VDSL and other superfast broadband (at least 30 Mbps download)

fields.label: Fixed broadband take-up (subscriptions/100 people)
fields.definition: Number of fixed broadband subscriptions (lines) per 100 people. Penetration of fixed broadband.

fields.label: Rural Fibre to the Premises coverage/availability (as a % of households)
fields.alt_label: Rural Fibre to the Premises coverage
fields.definition: Coverage is a supply indicator defined as the percentage of Households living in areas served by FTTP. Rural areas are defined as those with less than 100 people per km2.

fields.label: Rural NGA broadband coverage/availability (as a % of households)
fields.definition: Coverage is a supply indicator defined as the percentage of Households living in areas served by NGA. Next Generation Access includes the following technologies: FTTH, FTTB, Cable Docsis 3.0, VDSL and other superfast broadband (at least 30 Mbps download). Rural areas are defined as those with less than 100 people per km2.

fields.label: Rural Fixed Very High Capacity Network (VHCN) coverage
fields.alt_label: Rural Fixed Very High Capacity Network (VHCN) coverage
fields.definition: Percentage of households covered by any fixed VHCN. The technologies considered are FTTH and FTTB for 2015-2018 and FTTH, FTTB and Cable Docsis 3.1 for 2019 onwards.

fields.label: Standard fixed broadband coverage/availability (as a % of households)
fields.definition: Coverage is a supply indicator defined as the percentage of Households living in areas served by xDSL, cable (basic and NGA), FTTP or WiMax networks

fields.label: Share of fixed broadband subscriptions >= 10 Mbps - Advertised download speed
fields.alt_label: Share of fixed broadband subscriptions >= 10 Mbps
fields.definition: Based on advertised download speeds.

fields.label: Share of fixed broadband subscriptions >= 100 Mbps - Advertised download speed
fields.alt_label: Share of fixed broadband subscriptions >= 100 Mbps
fields.definition: Based on advertised download speeds.

fields.label: Share of fixed broadband subscriptions >= 2 Mbps - Advertised download speed
fields.alt_label: Share of fixed broadband subscriptions >= 2 Mbps
fields.definition: Based on advertised download speeds.

fields.label: Share of fixed broadband subscriptions >= 30 Mbps - Advertised download speed
fields.alt_label: Share of fixed broadband subscriptions >= 30 Mbps
fields.definition: Based on advertised download speeds.

fields.label: Rural standard fixed broadband coverage (as a % of households)
fields.definition: Coverage is a supply indicator defined as the percentage of Households living in areas served by xDSL, cable (basic and NGA), FTTP or WiMax networks. Rural areas are defined as those with less than 100 people per km2.

fields.label: Fixed Very High Capacity Network (VHCN) coverage
fields.alt_label: Fixed Very High Capacity Network (VHCN) coverage
fields.definition:
Percentage of households covered by any fixed VHCN. The technologies considered are FTTH and FTTB for 2015-2018 and FTTH, FTTB and Cable Docsis 3.1 for 2019 onwards.
Rural areas are defined as those with less than 100 people per km2.

fields.label: Business R&D expenditure of the ICT sector
fields.alt_label: Business R&D expenditure of the ICT sector
fields.definition: Intramural expenditures on R&D performed within business enterprise sector during a specific period, whatever the source of funds (Frascati Manual).

fields.label: Total bandwidth available in Géant
fields.definition: This is measured as total bandwidth available in the European GÉANT footprint (Gbpskms)  ( European dark fibre + European leased capacity excluding the connections to interconnections such as Internet2)
fields.note: As of June 2014 the revamping of the networking was achieved and due to a technology optimisation there are less lightened backup routes explaining the decrease in capacity.

fields.label: Computing cycles available for open transnational access in EGI
fields.definition: Computing cycles made available by EGI - the European Grid Infrastructure -, a federation of over 350 resource centres coordinated by a not-for-profit foundation which delivers integrated computing services to European researchers, co-funded by the European Commission.

fields.label: Computing cycles available for open transnational access in PRACE
fields.definition: Computing cycles allocated by PRACE - Partnership for Advanced Computing in Europe -, a project which delivers pan-European supercomputing infrastructure to European researchers, co-funded by the European Commission.

fields.label: Cross border Data traffic over the research networks
fields.definition: This is the total monthly volume of traffic transiting GÉANT. As reported in the GÉANT MSR, measured as the aggregated traffic over a month to and from the European NRENs and all world regions.
fields.note: As of 01/01/2015 the indicator is reset to integrate traffic that was not counted (Layer 1 & 2).

fields.label: Digital Economy and Society Index
fields.definition: DESI overall index, calculated as the weighted average of the four main DESI dimensions.

fields.label: 4G coverage
fields.definition: Percentage of populated areas with coverage by 4G

fields.label: 5G readiness
fields.definition: The amount of spectrum assigned and ready for 5G use by the end of 2020 within the so-called 5G pioneer bands. These bands are 700 MHz (703-733 MHz and 758-788 MHz), 3.6 GHz (3400-3800 MHz) and 26 GHz (1000 MHz within 24250-27500 MHz). All three spectrum bands have an equal weight

fields.label: 5G coverage
fields.definition: Percentage of populated areas with coverage by 5G

fields.label: Broadband price index
fields.definition: The broadband price index measures the prices of representative baskets of fixed, mobile and converged broadband offers

fields.label: Broadband price index
Fixed broadband coverage
Fixed broadband take-up
Mobile broadband
Connectivity
Digital Public Services
e-Government
e-Government Users
fields.definition: Individuals who used the Internet, in the last 12 months, for interaction with public authorities

fields.label: Open Data
fields.definition: This composite indicator measures to what extent countries have an open data policy in place (including the transposition of the revised PSI Directive), the estimated political, social and economic impact of open data and the characteristics (functionalities, data availability and usage) of the national data portal.

fields.label: Pre-filled Forms
fields.definition: Amount of data that is pre-filled in public services' online forms

fields.label: Digital public services for businesses
fields.definition: The indicator broadly reflects the share of public services needed for starting a business and conducting regular business operations that are available online for domestic as well as foreign users. Services provided through a portal receive a higher score, services which provide only information (but have to be completed offline) receive a more limited score.

fields.label: Digital public services for citizens
fields.definition: The share of administrative steps that can be done online for major life events (birth of a child, new residence, etc.) for citizens

fields.label: Fast BB (NGA) coverage
fields.definition: Percentage of households covered by fixed broadband of at least 30 Mbps download. The technologies considered are FTTH, FTTB, Cable Docsis 3.0 and VDS

fields.label: Overall fixed BB take-up
fields.definition: Percentage of households subscribing to fixed broadband

fields.label: At least 1 Gbps take-up
fields.definition: Percentage of households subscribing to fixed broadband of at least 1 Gbps, calculated as overall fixed broadband take-up

fields.label: Human Capital
Above basic digital skills
fields.definition: Individuals with ‘above basic’ digital skills in each of the following four dimensions: information, communication, problem solving and software for content creation (as measured by the number of activities carried out during the previous 3 months).

fields.label: At least basic software skills
fields.definition: Individuals who, in addition to having used basic software features such as word processing, have used advanced spreadsheet functions, created a presentation or document integrating text, pictures and tables or charts, or written code in a programming language.

fields.label: Advanced Skills and Development
At least Basic Digital Skills
fields.definition: Individuals with ‘basic’ or ‘above basic’ digital skills in each of the following four dimensions: information, communication, problem solving and software for content creation (as measured by the number of activities carried out during the previous 3 months).

fields.label: Internet User Skills
Enterprises providing ICT training
fields.definition: Enterprises who provided training in ICT to their personnel

fields.label: Female ICT specialists
fields.definition: Employed female ICT specialists. Broad definition based on the ISCO-08 classification and including jobs like ICT service managers, ICT professionals, ICT technicians, ICT installers and servicers.

fields.label: ICT graduates
fields.definition: Individuals with a degree in ICT

fields.label: ICT Specialists
fields.definition: Employed ICT specialists. Broad definition based on the ISCO-08 classification and including jobs like ICT service managers, ICT professionals, ICT technicians, ICT installers and servicers.

fields.label: Integration of Digital Technology
Artificial intelligence
fields.definition: Enterprises using at least 2 AI technologies

fields.label: Big data
fields.definition: Enterprises analysing big data from any data source

fields.label: Cloud
fields.definition: Enterprises purchasing at least one of the following cloud computing services: hosting of the enterprise's database, accounting software applications, CRM software, computing power

fields.label: Digital intensity
Digital technologies for businesses
e-Commerce
e-Commerce turnover
fields.definition: SMEs total turnover from e-commerce

fields.label: e-Invoices
fields.definition: Enterprises sending e-invoices, suitable for automated processing

fields.label: Electronic Information Sharing
fields.definition: Enterprises who have in use an ERP (enterprise resource planning) software package to share information between different functional areas (e.g. accounting, planning, production, marketing)

fields.label: ICT for environmental sustainability
fields.definition: The indicator measures the level of support that adopted ICT technologies offered to enterprises to engage in more environmentally-friendly actions. The level of intensity is measured based on the number of environmental actions (maximum 10) reported by enterprises to have been facilitated by the use of ICT. The following categorisation was achieved: low intensity (0 to 4 actions), medium intensity (5 to 7 actions) and high intensity (8 to 10 actions).

fields.label: Selling online cross-border
fields.definition: SMEs that carried out electronic sales to other EU countries

fields.label: SMEs with at least a basic level of digital intensity
fields.alt_label: SMEs with at least a basic level of digital intensity
fields.definition: The digital intensity score is based on counting how many out of 12 selected technologies are used by enterprises. A basic level requires usage of at least 4 technologies.

fields.label: SMEs selling online
fields.definition: SMEs selling online (at least 1% of turnover)

fields.label: Social media
fields.definition: Enterprises using two or more of the following social media: social networks, enterprise's blog or microblog, multimedia content sharing websites, wiki-based knowledge sharing tools. Using social media means that the enterprise has a user profile, an account or a user license depending on the requirements and the type of the social media.

fields.label: Mobile BB take-up
fields.definition: Number of mobile data subscriptions per 100 people

fields.label: Digital Economy and Society Index
fields.definition: DESI overall index, calculated as the weighted average of the four main DESI dimensions with the weights selected by the user.

fields.label: Digital Economy and Society Index
fields.definition: DESI overall index score per country

fields.label: At least 100 Mbps fixed BB take-up
fields.alt_label: At least 100 Mbps fixed broadband take-up
fields.definition: Percentage of households subscribing to fixed broadband of at least 100 Mbps, calculated as overall fixed broadband take-up

fields.label: Fixed Very High Capacity Network (VHCN) coverage
fields.alt_label: Fixed Very High Capacity Network (VHCN) coverage
fields.definition: Percentage of households covered by any fixed VHCN. The technologies considered are FTTH and FTTB for 2015-2018 and FTTH, FTTB and Cable Docsis 3.1 for 201

fields.label: Enterprises exchanging business documents suitable for automatic processing
fields.definition: The indicator refers to sending/receiving of messages (orders, invoices, payment transactions, transport documents, tax declarations, etc.) to/from other enterprises, public authorities or financial institutions in an agreed or standard format (as EDIFACT, XML, etc) which allows their automatic processing without the individual message being manually typed.
fields.note: Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector. Breaks in series because until 2008 economic activities according to NACE Rev 1.1 and from 2009 data are based on NACE Rev.2. Since 2010 data include also sector S 95.1-Repair of computers and communication equipment.

fields.label: Enterprises paying to advertise on the internet
fields.alt_label: Enterprises paying to advertise on the internet
fields.definition: Enterprises paying to advertise on the internet
fields.note: Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector. Breaks in series because until 2008 economic activities according to NACE Rev 1.1 and from 2009 data are based on NACE Rev.2. Since 2010 data include also sector S 95.1-Repair of computers and communication equipment.

fields.label: Enterprises advertising online based on the geolocation of internet users
fields.alt_label: Enterprises advertising online based on the geolocation of internet users
fields.definition: Pay to advertise on the internet, based on the geolocation of internet users

fields.label: Enterprises tracking internet users for targeted advertising
fields.alt_label: Enterprises tracking internet users for targeted advertising
fields.definition: Pay to advertise on the internet, based on the tracking of internet users' past activities or profile

fields.label: Enterprises having done electronic sales to other EU countries in the last calender year
fields.alt_label: Enterprises selling cross-border to other EU countries
fields.definition: The sales have been realised, during the previous calendar year, via any computer networks (in monetary terms, excluding VAT). Computer networks include websites, EDI-type systems and other means of electronic data transfer, excluding manually typed e-mails.
fields.note: Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector. Breaks in series because until 2008 economic activities according to NACE Rev 1.1 and from 2009 data are based on NACE Rev.2. Since 2010 data include also sector S 95.1-Repair of computers and communication equipment.

fields.label: Enterprises using AI technologies
fields.definition: Enterprises using at least one of the following AI technologies: analysis of written language, converting spoken language into machine-readable format, generating written or spoken language,  identifying objects or persons based on images,  machine learning (e.g. deep learning), automating different workflows or assisting in decision making or enabling physical movement of machines via autonomous decisions based on observation of surroundings

fields.label: Enterprises selling via a website or apps by geographical location of the costumer
fields.alt_label: Enterprises selling via a website or apps by geographical location
fields.definition: Share of the enterprises that, during the previous calendar year, received orders by costumers located in the own country, other EU countries or the rest of the world
fields.note: Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector. Breaks in series because until 2008 economic activities according to NACE Rev 1.1 and from 2009 data are based on NACE Rev.2. Since 2010 data include also sector S 95.1-Repair of computers and communication equipment.

fields.label: Enterprises using e-Commerce marketplace for sales
fields.definition: Share of enterprises that, during the previous calendar year, received orders for goods or services via an e-Commerce marketplace
fields.note: Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector. Breaks in series because until 2008 economic activities according to NACE Rev 1.1 and from 2009 data are based on NACE Rev.2. Since 2010 data include also sector S 95.1-Repair of computers and communication equipment.

fields.label: Enterprises using  their own website or apps for sales
fields.alt_label: Enterprises selling via own website or apps
fields.definition: Share of enterprises that, during the previous calendar year, received orders for goods or services via their own website or apps.
fields.note: Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector. Breaks in series because until 2008 economic activities according to NACE Rev 1.1 and from 2009 data are based on NACE Rev.2. Since 2010 data include also sector S 95.1-Repair of computers and communication equipment.

fields.label: Enterprises exploiting the "Business to Consumers" opportunities of web sales
fields.alt_label: Enterprises exploiting B2C opportunities of web sales
fields.definition: Enterprises where web sales are more than 1% of total turnover and B2C web sales more than 10% of the web sales
fields.note: Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector. Breaks in series because since 2010 data include also sector S 95.1-Repair of computers and communication equipment.

fields.label: Sells via marketplace  as a pecentage of turnover
fields.definition: The value of sales made during the previous calendar year, via an e-Commerce marketplace in % of the total turnover value (in monetary terms, excluding VAT).
fields.note: Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector. Breaks in series because until 2008 economic activities according to NACE Rev 1.1 and from 2009 data are based on NACE Rev.2. Since 2010 data include also sector S 95.1-Repair of computers and communication equipment.

fields.label: Sells via own website or apps as a pecentage of turnover
fields.alt_label: Sells via own website or apps
fields.definition: The value of sales made during the previous calendar year, via their own website or apps in % of the total turnover value (in monetary terms, excluding VAT).
fields.note: Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector. Breaks in series because until 2008 economic activities according to NACE Rev 1.1 and from 2009 data are based on NACE Rev.2. Since 2010 data include also sector S 95.1-Repair of computers and communication equipment.

fields.label: Enterprises analysing big data from any data source
fields.alt_label: Enterprises analysing big data from any data source (until 2018)
fields.definition: Analyse big data from any data source

fields.label: Enterprises analysing big data (2020)
fields.alt_label: Enterprises analysing big data from any data source
fields.definition: Analyse big data internally from any data source or externally

fields.label: Enterprises having a fixed broadband connection
fields.alt_label: Enterprises with a fixed broadband connection
fields.definition: Fixed broadband connections include DSL, xDSL, cable leased lines, Frame Relay, Metro-Ethernet, PLC-Powerline communications, fixed wireless connections, etc.
fields.note: Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector. Breaks in series because until 2008 economic activities according to NACE Rev 1.1 and from 2009 data are based on NACE Rev.2. Since 2010 data include also sector S 95.1-Repair of computers and communication equipment.

fields.label: Buy Cloud Computing services used over the internet
fields.definition: Cloud computing refers to purchased ICT services that have all of the following characteristics: are delivered from servers of service providers; can be easily scaled up or down; can be used on-demand by the user without human interaction with the service provider; are paid for, either per user, by capacity used, or they are pre-paid.Eurostat variable e_cc_ge_me
fields.note: Cloud computing may include connections via Virtual Private Networks (VPN). Optional question in 2015, not all countries have collected the indicator.

fields.label: Enterprises buying sophisticated or intermediate cloud computing services
fields.alt_label: Enterprises buying sophisticated or intermediate cloud computing services
fields.definition: Enterprises purchasing at least one of the following cloud computing services: accounting/finance/ERP software, CRM software, hosting for the enterprise's database, hosted environment for application development

fields.label: Buy Cloud Computing services of medium-high sophistication
fields.definition: Enterprises purchasing at least one of the following cloud computing services: hosting of the enterprise's database, accounting software applications, CRM software, computing power.
fields.note: Computed from Eurostat database with the following formula = (e_cc_me) - (e_cc_lo) + (e_cc_hi). Optional question in 2015, not all countries have collected the indicator.

fields.label: Enterprises buying computing power in the Cloud
fields.alt_label: Enterprises buying computing power to run own software in the Cloud
fields.definition: Cloud computing refers to purchased ICT services that have all of the following characteristics: are delivered from servers of service providers; can be easily scaled up or down; can be used on-demand by the user without human interaction with the service provider; are paid for, either per user, by capacity used, or they are pre-paid.
fields.note: Optional question in 2015, not all countries have collected the indicator.

fields.label: Enterprises using Customer Relationship Management (CRM) software
fields.definition: CRM refers to the use of any software application used for the analysis of information about clients for marketing purposes.
fields.note: Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector. Breaks in series because until 2008 economic activities according to NACE Rev 1.1 and from 2009 data are based on NACE Rev.2. Since 2010 data include also sector S 95.1-Repair of computers and communication equipment.

fields.label: Enterprises with high digital intensity index (DII v3)
fields.alt_label: Enterprises with high digital intensity index (DII v3)
fields.definition: Enterprises with high digital intensity index (DII v3)

fields.label: Enterprises with low digital intensity index (DII v3)
fields.alt_label: Enterprises with low digital intensity index (DII v3)
fields.definition: Enterprises with low digital intensity index (DII v3)

fields.label: Enterprises with very high digital intensity index (DII v3)
fields.alt_label: Enterprises with very high digital intensity index (DII v3)
fields.definition: Enterprises with very high digital intensity index (DII v3)

fields.label: Enterprises with very low digital intensity index (DII v3)
fields.alt_label: Enterprises with very low digital intensity index (DII v3)
fields.definition: Enterprises with very low digital intensity index (DII v3)

fields.label: Enterprises with High levels of Digital Intensity
fields.alt_label: Enterprises with High levels of Digital Intensity
fields.definition: The Digital Intensity score is based on counting how many out of 12 technologies are used by each enterprise. High levels are attributed to those enterprises using at least 7 of the listed digital technologies.
fields.note:
The 2015 list of technologies includes: usage of internet by a majority of the workers; access to ICT specialist skills; fixed broadband speed > 30 Mbps; mobile devices used by more than 20% of employed persons; has a website; has some sophisticated functions on the website; presence on social media; does e-sales for at least 1% of turnover; exploit the B2C opportunities of web sales; use an ERP software; use a CRM software; share electronically supply chain management information.
In 2016 the last 3 indicators have been replaced with: pay to advertise on the internet; purchase cloud computing advanced services; send eInvoices. There is thus a break in series with in general a reduction of the digital intensity scores.

fields.label: Enterprises with Very Low level of Digital Intensity
fields.alt_label: Enterprises with Very Low level of Digital Intensity
fields.definition: The Digital Intensity score is based on counting how many out of 12 technologies are used by each enterprise. Very Low levels are attributed to those enterprises using no more than 3 of the listed digital technologies.
fields.note:
The 2015 list of technologies includes: usage of internet by a majority of the workers; access to ICT specialist skills; fixed broadband speed > 30 Mbps; mobile devices used by more than 20% of employed persons; has a website; has some sophisticated functions on the website; presence on social media; does e-sales for at least 1% of turnover; exploit the B2C opportunities of web sales; use an ERP software; use a CRM software; share electronically supply chain management information.
In 2016 the last 3 indicators have been replaced with: pay to advertise on the internet; purchase cloud computing advanced services; send eInvoices. There is thus a break in series with in general a reduction of the digital intensity scores.

fields.label: Enterprises using any computer network for purchases (at least 1%)
fields.definition: The purchases realised, during the previous calendar year, via any computer networks should represent at least 1% of the total purchases value (in monetary terms, excluding VAT). Computer networks include websites, EDI-type systems and other means of electronic data transfer, excluding manually typed e-mails.
fields.note: Since 2011 the indicator is optional, so EU27 estimates cover less countries and are not comparable with previous years. Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector. Breaks in series because until 2008 economic activities according to NACE Rev 1.1 and from 2009 data are based on NACE Rev.2. Since 2010 data include also sector S 95.1-Repair of computers and communication equipment.

fields.label: Enterprises providing portable devices to more than 20% of their employed persons
fields.alt_label: Enterprises providing portable devices to > 20% of their employed persons
fields.definition: The devices (portable computers, tablets, smartphones, PDA phones, etc.) should be provided for business use and the enterprises pay for all or at least up to a limit the subscription and the use costs.
fields.note: Only the 2011 question was limited to portable devices using at least 3G technology to connect to the internet. Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector.

fields.label: Enterprises that share internally electronic information with an ERP
fields.alt_label: Integration of internal processes (with an ERP)
fields.definition: Have in use an ERP-Enterprise resource planning software package, to share information between different functional areas (e.g. accounting, planning, production, marketing).
fields.note: Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector. Breaks in series because until 2008 economic activities according to NACE Rev 1.1 and from 2009 data are based on NACE Rev.2. Since 2010 data include also sector S 95.1-Repair of computers and communication equipment. Break in series in 2012 due to different wording of the question.

fields.label: Enterprises using any computer network for sales (at least 1%)
fields.definition: The sales realised, during the previous calendar year, via any computer networks should represent at least 1% of the total turnover value (in monetary terms, excluding VAT). Computer networks include websites, EDI-type systems and other means of electronic data transfer, excluding manually typed e-mails.
fields.note: Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector. Breaks in series because until 2008 economic activities according to NACE Rev 1.1 and from 2009 data are based on NACE Rev.2. Since 2010 data include also sector S 95.1-Repair of computers and communication equipment.

fields.label: Total electronic sales by enterprises, as a % of their total turnover
fields.definition: The value of sales realised, during the previous calendar year, via any computer networks in % of the total turnover value (in monetary terms, excluding VAT). Computer networks include websites, EDI-type systems and other means of electronic data transfer, excluding manually typed e-mails.
fields.note: Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector. Breaks in series because until 2008 economic activities according to NACE Rev 1.1 and from 2009 data are based on NACE Rev.2. Since 2010 data include also sector S 95.1-Repair of computers and communication equipment.

fields.label: 0 Overall Score
fields.definition: The overall eGovernment maturity score that captures the scores of all four dimensions, which consist of 14 underlying indicators, broken down into 48 survey questions

fields.label: 1 User centricity
fields.definition: The extent to which information and services are available online, supported online and compatible with mobile devices.D362

fields.label: 1 User Centricity
fields.definition: The extent to which (information about) a public service is provided online, how the online journey is supported and if public websites are mobile friendly.
fields.note:
Composite indicator:
(2016-2017) weighted average of Online availability (67%), Usability (22%) and Mobile Friendliness (11%).
(2012-2015) weighted average of Online availability (67%), Usability (17%), Ease of Use (8%) and Speed of Use (8%)
Break in series in 2016 (no data displayed for breakdown:Total 2016).

fields.label: 1.1 User centricity - Online availability
fields.definition: The extent to which informational and transactional services and information concerning these services is provided online, and can be reached via a portal website.

fields.label: 1a User Centricity - Online availability
fields.definition: The extent to which a Public Service or information concerning the public service is provided online, and via a portal.

fields.label: 1.2 User centricity - Mobile friendliness
fields.definition: The extent to which services are provided through a mobile-friendly interface, an interface that is responsive to the mobile device.

fields.label: 1b User Centricity - Usability
fields.definition: Indicates if support, help and (interactive) feedback functionalities for the online public service are available.

fields.label: 1.3 User centricity - User support
fields.definition: The extent to which online support, help features, and feedback mechanisms are available.

fields.label: 1c User Centricity - Mobile Friendliness
fields.definition: The ability to provide public services through a mobile-friendly interface; an interface that is ‘adapted’ to the mobile device. The data collection for this indicator is done via an automated tool.
fields.note: The new key enabler “Mobile Friendliness” was introduced in 2016. Mobile friendliness was also measured in 2014 and 2015 as proof-of-concept indicator. It was not part of the calculation of the User Centricity Benchmark in those years, but presented as separate index. In 2016, mobile friendliness of both individual services’ websites as well as generic portals is integrated as a component of the Online Usability and User Centricity composite indicators.

fields.label: 1d User Centricity - Ease of Use
fields.definition: Quality assessment by researchers indicating how intuitively and smoothly the online process steps for obtaining a public service can be completed.  It assesses  the extent to which the user achieved his/her goal, understood what he/she was supposed to do for obtaining the service, he/she found the succession of the process steps logical and he/she was actively engaged to improve the service.
fields.note: This indicator has been discontinued starting from 2016

fields.label: 1e User Centricity - Speed of Use
fields.definition: Quality assessment researchers indicating if  the online process steps for obtaining a public service could be completed within reasonable amount of time. It assesses the extent to which citizens or businesses are able to submit information to the authority (or information was pre-filled), the time needed to obtain the service and the extent to which the services were structured efficiently.
fields.note: This indicator has been discontinued starting from 2016

fields.label: 2 Transparency
fields.definition:
The extent to which governments are transparent with regard to:
a) the process of public service delivery
b) their own responsibilities and performance
c) the personal data involved in service delivery
This top-level benchmark evaluates the transparency of government authorities’ operations, service delivery procedures as well as with regard to the consultation of personal data by public administrations.
fields.note: Composite indicator: simple average of (Transparency) Service Delivery, Public Organisations and Personal Data

fields.label: 2 Transparency
fields.definition: The extent to which service processes are transparent, services are designed with user involvement and users can manage their personal data.

fields.label: 2a Transparency - Service delivery
fields.definition: The extent to which public administrations inform users about the public service itself, setting expectations on timeliness, process and delivery for citizens and entrepreneurs from the moment a user request a service until the service is delivered.

fields.label: 2.1 Transparency - Transparency of service delivery
fields.definition: The extent to which the service process and expectations are clarified.

fields.label: 2b Transparency - Public organisations
fields.definition: The extent to which public administrations publish information about their organisations (e.g. finance, organisational structure and responsibilities), and about their activities (e.g. the decision-making processes and regulations).

fields.label: 2.2 Transparency - Transparency of personal data
fields.definition: The extent to which user can manage their personal data held by government organisations.

fields.label: 2c Transparency - Personal data
fields.definition: The extent to which governments proactively inform users about how, when, and by whom their personal data is being processed
fields.note: In 2016, an additional question was added to the questionnaire for this indicator.

fields.label: 2.3 Transparency - Transparency of service design
fields.definition: The extent to which user are informed on and involved in policy and service design processes.

fields.label: 2.X Transparency - Transparency of public organisations (old indicator)
fields.alt_label: 2.X Transparency - Transparency of public organisations (old indicator)
fields.definition: The extent to which public administrations publish information about their organisations (e.g. finance, organisational structure and responsibilities), and about their activities (e.g. the decision-making processes and regulations).
fields.note: This indicator has been discontinued starting from 2020

fields.label: 3 Citizen Mobility
fields.definition: The extent to which public services that are aimed at foreign  citizens are available online, usable, and implement eID and eDocument capabilities
fields.note:
Composite indicator:
(2016-2017) weighted average of (Citizen Mobility) Online Availability (50%), Usability (25%), eID Cross Borders (12%) and eDocuments Cross Borders (12%).
(2012-2015) weighted average of (Citizen Mobility) Online Availability (67%), Usability (17%), Ease of Use (8%) and Speed of Use (8%)
Break in series in 2016 (no data displayed for breakdown:Total 2016).

fields.label: 3 Key Enablers
fields.definition: The extent to which main IT enablers (eIDs, eDocuments, Authentic sources, Digital post and security) are available during services processes, which can be used to assess the presence of the technical pre-conditions of the efficient and effective use of online services.

fields.label: 3a Citizen Mobility - Online availability
fields.definition: The extent to which a public service (or information concerning the service) aimed at foreign citizens  is available online.

fields.label: 3.1 Key enablers - eID
fields.definition: The extent to which electronic Identification (eID), any means accepted by eGovernment services (e.g. smartcards, username and password) for online identification, can be used during service processes.

fields.label: 3b Citizen Mobility - Usability
fields.definition: Online support and help features on services aimed at foreign citizens.

fields.label: 3.2 Key enabler - eDocuments
fields.definition: The extent to which electronic documents (eDocuments), any document in digital form that the user needs to submit/upload in order to complete an eGovernment service, or that the user obtains as a proof or a result of the service (e.g. certificate, diploma, proof of registration) can be used during service processes.

fields.label: 3c Citizen Mobility - eID Cross Borders
fields.definition: The possibility of using a foreign eID for accessing citizen services.
fields.note: New indicator, introduced in 2016.

fields.label: 3.3 Key enabler - Authentic sources
fields.definition: The extent to which Authentic Sources, base registries used by governments to automatically validate or fetch data relating to citizens or businesses, can be used during the service process.

fields.label: 3d Citizen Mobility - eDocuments Cross Borders
fields.definition: The possibility of sending/receiving eDocuments for a foreigner using citizen services
fields.note: New indicator, introduced in 2016.

fields.label: 3.4 Key enabler - Digital Post
fields.definition: The extent to which public authorities allow citizens to receive communications digitally only and opt-out for paper mailings. Digital Post refers to the possibility that governments communicate electronically-only with citizens or entrepreneurs through e.g. personal mailboxes or other digital postal solutions.

fields.label: 3e Citizen Mobility - Ease of Use
fields.definition: Quality assessment by researchers indicating how intuitively and smoothly the online process steps for obtaining a public service can be completed by a foreign citizen.  It assesses  the extent to which the user achieved his/her goal, understood what he/she was supposed to do for obtaining the service, he/she found the succession of the process steps logical and he/she was actively engaged to improve the service.
fields.note: This indicator has been discontinued starting from 2016

fields.label: 3f Citizen Mobility - Speed of Use
fields.definition: Quality assessment researchers indicating if  the online process steps for obtaining a public service could be completed within reasonable amount of time by a foreign citizen. It assesses the extent to which (foreign) citizens are able to submit information to the authority (or information was pre-filled), the time needed to obtain the service and the extent to which the services were structured efficiently.
fields.note: This indicator has been discontinued starting from 2016

fields.label: 4 Business Mobility
fields.definition: The extent to which public services that are aimed at foreign  businesses are available online, usable, and implement eID and eDocument capabilities
fields.note:
Composite indicator:
(2016-2017) weighted average of (Business Mobility) Online Availability (50%), Usability (25%), eID Cross Borders (12%) and eDocuments Cross Borders (12%).
(2012-2015) weighted average of (Business Mobility) Online Availability (67%), Usability (17%), Ease of Use (8%) and Speed of Use (8%)
Break in series in 2016 (no data displayed for breakdown:Total 2016).

fields.label: 4 Cross-border services
fields.definition: The extent to which information and services are available online, usable, and integrated with eIDs and eDocuments for users from other European countries.

fields.label: 4a Business Mobility - Online availability
fields.definition: The extent to which a public service (or information concerning the service) aimed at foreign businesses  is available online.

fields.label: 4.1 Cross-border services - Cross-border online availability
fields.definition: The extent to which informational and transactional services and information concerning these services is provided online for users from other European countries.

fields.label: 4b Business Mobility - Usability
fields.definition: Online support and help features on services aimed at foreign businesses.

fields.label: 4.2 Cross-border services - Cross-border user support
fields.definition: The extent to which online support, help features, and feedback mechanisms are available for users from other European countries.

fields.label: 4c Business Mobility - eID Cross Borders
fields.definition: The possibility of using a foreign eID for accessing business services.
fields.note: New indicator, introduced in 2016.

fields.label: 4.3 Cross-border services - Cross-border eID
fields.definition: The extent to which electronic Identification (eID) can be used during service processes by users from other European countries, a government-issued document for online identification, and authentication.

fields.label: 4d Business Mobility - eDocuments Cross Borders
fields.definition: The possibility of sending/receiving eDocuments for a foreigner using business services
fields.note: New indicator, introduced in 2016.

fields.label: 4.4 Cross-border services - Cross-border eDocuments
fields.definition: The extent to which electronic documents (eDocuments) can be used during service processes by users from other European countries, documents that have been authenticated by its issuer using any means recognised under applicable national law, specifically through the use of electronic signatures, e.g. not a regular PDF or Word file.

fields.label: 4e Business Mobility - Ease of Use
fields.definition: Quality assessment by researchers indicating how intuitively and smoothly the online process steps for obtaining a public service can be completed by a foreign business.  It assesses  the extent to which the user achieved his/her goal, understood what he/she was supposed to do for obtaining the service, he/she found the succession of the process steps logical and he/she was actively engaged to improve the service.
fields.note: This indicator has been discontinued starting from 2016

fields.label: 4f Business Mobility - Speed of Use
fields.definition: Quality assessment researchers indicating if  the online process steps for obtaining a public service could be completed within reasonable amount of time by a foreign business. It assesses the extent to which (foreign) businesses are able to submit information to the authority (or information was pre-filled), the time needed to obtain the service and the extent to which the services were structured efficiently.
fields.note: This indicator has been discontinued starting from 2016

fields.label: 5 Key Enablers
fields.definition:
The extent to which technical pre-conditions for eGovernment service provision are used. The key enablers used for measuring the quality of the services to businesses and citizens are:
a) Electronic Identification (eID)
b) Electronic Documents (eDocuments)
c) Authentic Sources
d) Digital Post
e) eSafe (now discontinued)
f) Single Sign On (SSO) (now discontinued)
fields.note:
Composite indicator:
(2016-2017) simple average of eID, eDocuments, Authentic Sources and Digital Post.
(2012-2015) simple average of eID, eDocuments, Authentic Sources, eSafe and Single Sign On.
Break in series in 2016 as the  eSafe and Single Sign On are discontinued and Digital Post is added.

fields.label: 5a Key Enablers - eID
fields.definition: Electronic Identification (eID) is a government-issued document for online identification, and authentication.

fields.label: 5b Key Enablers - eDocuments
fields.definition: A document which has been authenticated by its issuer using any means recognised under applicable national law, specifically through the use of electronic signatures, e.g. not a regular pdf or word document.

fields.label: 5c Key Enablers - Authentic sources
fields.definition: Authentic Sources are base registries used by governments to automatically validate or fetch data relating to citizens or businesses.

fields.label: 5d Key Enablers - Digital Post
fields.definition: Assesses whether public authorities allow citizens to receive communications digitally only, and hence reducing paper mailings. Digital Post refers to the possibility that governments communicate electronically-only with citizens or entrepreneurs through e.g. personal mailboxes or other digital post solutions.
fields.note: New indicator, introduced in 2016.

fields.label: 5e Key Enablers - eSafe
fields.definition: A virtual repository for storing, administering and sharing personal electronic data and documents. It can be used to securely store personal documents in public service processes.
fields.note: This indicator has been discontinued starting from 2016

fields.label: 5f Key Enablers - Single Sign On (SSO)
fields.definition: A functionality that allows users to get access to multiple websites without the need to log in multiple times.
fields.note: This indicator has been discontinued starting from 2016

fields.label: Digital Public Services for Citizens
fields.definition: The extent to which a service or information concerning service for citizens is provided online, and via a portal. Services that are offered fully, partially or not at all online.
fields.note:
It is calculated as the average of the national and cross-border online availability for basic and extended services within the citizen-related Life Events from the last two
years (Family, Career, Studying, Moving, Owning and driving a car and Starting a small claims procedure).

fields.label: Digital Public Services for Businesses
fields.definition: The extent to which a service or information concerning service for businesses is provided online and via a portal. Services that are offered fully, partially or not at all online.
fields.note:
It is calculated as the average of the national and cross-border online availability for basic and extended services within the business-related Life Events from the last two
years (Business Start-up and Regular Business
Operations). Until 2019 (included), the indicator was measuring Basic services for National and Cross-Border. Meaning that as of 2020, the extended services were also added.
The data was recalculated to include EU27 Average.

fields.label: Key Enablers
fields.definition: Availability of Key Enablers such as electronic Identification (eID), electronic Documents, Authentic Sources as well as Digital Post (newly introduced in 2017)
fields.note: The degree to which key enablers (eID, eDocuments. Authentic sources, Digital Post) are available for interaction with public administration for the life events (Business, Family, Job, Studying)

fields.label: Open Data
fields.definition: A series of indicators have been selected to measure Open Data maturity across Europe. These indicators cover the level of development of national policies promoting Open Data, an assessment of the features made available on national data portals as well as the expected impact and quality of Open Data.
fields.note:
This composite indicator comprises 4 dimensions:
i)Open Data Policy that focuses on the presence of specific  olicies and strategies to foster open data at national level; 
ii) Open Data Impact that looks at the activities performed to monitor and measure open re-use and the impact derived by such re-use; 
iii) Open Data Portal that focuses on advanced portal  unctions that enable both versed and less versed users to access open data via the national portal and features that enhance the interaction between publishers and re-users (via forum and discussion boards); and 
iv) Open Data Quality that focuses on the measures  dopted by portal managers to ensure the systematic harvesting of metadata from sources across the country, as well as the  urrency of the available metadata and where possible the actual data, the monitoring of the compliance with the DCAT-AP metadata standard as well as the quality of  eployment of the published data.
Break in series in 2020 due to methodological changes.
The data was recalculated to include EU27 Average.
For more information please consult: https://www.europeandataportal.eu/en/impact-studies/open-data-maturity

fields.label: Openness of Public Administrations
fields.definition: Openness of Member States in regards to Open Data, freedom of expression, free media and freedom of association.
fields.note: Composed indicator made of open data (DESI) and voice and accountability (World Bank indicator)

fields.label: Online Service Completion
fields.definition: Share of the steps in a Public Service life event that can be completed online (Online availability sub-indicator for User centricity of the eGovernment benchmark)
fields.note:
The indicator was measuring: Basic and Extended services for National services only till 2019. From 2020 the new indicator, "Digital Public Services for Citizens", was introduced. Together with the "Digital Public Services for Business' they are fully covering the spectrum of online services. 
The data was recalculated to include EU27 Average.

fields.label: Pre-filled forms
fields.definition: Amount of data that is pre-filled in Public Services' online forms (Authentic sources Key Enabler indicator of eGovernment benchmark)
fields.note: The data was recalculated to include EU27 Average.

fields.label: Enterprises interacting online with public authorities
fields.definition: Use of internet for interaction with public authorities, in the last calendar year before the survey, includes: obtaining information or forms from websites, returning filled in forms, following administrative procedures completely electronically or offering products in public authorities' electronic procurement sustems (eTendering).
fields.note: Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed, all manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector. Break in series in 2011 and 2012 because the structure of the question has changed. Breaks in series because until 2008 sectors follow economic activities according to NACE Rev 1.1 and from 2009 data are based on NACE Rev.2. Since 2010 data include also sector S 95.1-Repair of computers and communication equipment.

fields.label: Enterprises submitting a proposal in a public electronic tender system (eProcurement)
fields.definition: Tender proposals should have been submitted in the system itself and not by email, in the last calendar year before the survey.
fields.note: Data from previous years are not comparable because the structure of the question has changed. Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed, carrying out this activity over the internet in the last calendar year before the survey. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector.

fields.label: Enterprises returning filled in forms to public authorities, over the internet
fields.alt_label: Returning filled forms to eGov services - enterprises
fields.definition: Activity carried out over the internet, in the last calendar year before the survey.
fields.note: Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. Break in series in 2011 and 2012 because the question has changed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector. Breaks in series because until 2008 economic activities according to NACE Rev 1.1 and from 2009 data are based on NACE Rev.2. Since Since 2010 data include also sector S 95.1-Repair of computers and communication equipment.

fields.label: Enterprises sending or receiving e-invoices in a format suitable for automatic processing
fields.definition: The indicator refers to sending/receiving invoices in an agreed standard format (as EDIFACT, XML, etc) which allows their automatic processing, without the individual message being manually typed
fields.note: Important break in series due to a more detailed question since 2011. Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector. Breaks in series because until 2008 economic activities according to NACE Rev 1.1 and from 2009 data are based on NACE Rev.2. Since 2010 data include also sector S 95.1-Repair of computers and communication equipment.

fields.label: Enterprises sending e-invoices
fields.definition: Enterprises sending eInvoices, suitable for automatic processing

fields.label: Enterprises sending e-invoices (derived indicator, until 2017)
fields.definition: The indicator refers to sending invoices in an agreed standard format (as EDIFACT, XML, etc) which allows their automatic processing, without the individual message being manually typed. Eurostat variable e_inv3sbg_ap_gt0
fields.note: Break in series in 2011 because of a new more precise question. Break in series in 2014 because of introduction of a limitation to invoices sent to business or public organisations.

fields.label: Enterprises having a fast fixed broadband connection
fields.alt_label: Enterprises having a fast fixed broadband connection
fields.definition: The maximum contracted download speed of the fastest fixed internet connection is at least 30 Mb/s

fields.label: The speed of the fixed connection to internet  is not sufficient for the actual needs of the enterprise
fields.alt_label: Internet fixed connection speed is not sufficient
fields.definition: Number of enterprises reporting that the speed of the fixed connection(s) to the internet is usually not sufficient for the actual  needs of the enterprise
fields.note: Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector. Breaks in series because until 2008 economic activities according to NACE Rev 1.1 and from 2009 data are based on NACE Rev.2. Since 2010 data include also sector S 95.1-Repair of computers and communication equipment.

fields.label: The speed of the fixed connection to internet (at least 100 Mb/s) is not sufficient for the actual needs of the enterprise
fields.alt_label: Internet fixed connection speed of 100Mb/s is not sufficient
fields.definition: Number of enterprises reporting that the speed of the fixed connection(s) to the internet (at least 100 Mb/s) is usually not sufficient for the actual  needs of the enterprise
fields.note: Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector. Breaks in series because until 2008 economic activities according to NACE Rev 1.1 and from 2009 data are based on NACE Rev.2. Since 2010 data include also sector S 95.1-Repair of computers and communication equipment.

fields.label: Enterprises where ICT functions are mainly performed by external suppliers
fields.alt_label: Enterprises where ICT functions are mainly performed by external suppliers
fields.definition: The majority of ICT functions, out of a list of seven, are mainly performed by external suppliers and not by own employees or by ICT specialist in parent or affiliate enterprises. The functions include: maintenance of ICT infrastructures, support for office software, development and support for web solutions or business management software/systems (e.g. ERP, CRM, HR, databases), security and data protection.
fields.note: Detailed results are available in the Eurostat table ISOC_CI_EU_EN2.

fields.label: Enterprises employing ICT specialists
fields.definition: ICT specialists are employees for whom ICT is the main job. For example, to develop, operate or maintain ICT systems or applications.
fields.note: Limited comparability between 2007 and 2012 because of changes in the wording of the question. Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector.

fields.label: Enterprises reporting hard-to-fill vacancies for jobs requiring ICT specialist skills
fields.alt_label: Enterprises reporting hard-to-fill vacancies for ICT specialist
fields.definition: Hard-to-fill vacancies during the previous calendar year refer to a range of situations in which enterprises find it difficult to find persons with particular skills (hard-to-fill vacancies due to skills shortage).
fields.note: Limited comparability between 2007 and 2012 because of changes in the wording of the question. Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector.

fields.label: Enterprise provided training to their personnel to develop/upgrade their ICT skills
fields.alt_label: Enterprise provided training to their personnel to develop/upgrade their ICT skills
fields.definition: Detailed results are available in the Eurostat table ISOC_SKE_ITTN2.

fields.label: Enterprises providing portable devices to some of their persons employed
fields.alt_label: Enterprises providing portable devices to persons employed
fields.definition: The devices (portable computers, tablets, smartphones, PDA phones, etc.) should be provided for business use and the enterprises pay for all or at least up to a limit the subscription and the use costs.
fields.note: The 2011 question was limited to portable devices using at least 3G technology to connect to the internet. Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector.

fields.label: Enterprises using mobile Internet to run business applications
fields.alt_label: Enterprises using mobile Internet to run business applications
fields.definition: Mobile connection to the Internet for business use to use dedicated business software applications

fields.label: Enterprises providing persons employed a remote access to the enterprise's e-mail system, documents or applications
fields.alt_label: Enterprises providing persons employed a remote access to the IT system
fields.note: Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector.

fields.label: Enterprises using RFID technologies for person identification or access control
fields.alt_label: Enterprises using RFID for person identification or access control
fields.definition: RFID tags or transponders are devices that can be applied to or incorporated into a product or object and transmits data via radiowaves.

fields.label: Enterprises using Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) technologies
fields.alt_label: Use of Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) technologies
fields.definition: RFID tags or transponders are devices that can be applied to or incorporated into a product or object and transmits data via radiowaves. The indicator includes their use for person identification, for tracking of supply chain and inventory or for after-sales product identification.
fields.note: Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector. Since 2010 data include also sector S95.1-Repair of computers and communication equipment. Biennial indicator not collected in 2010.

fields.label: Enterprises using RFID for product identification
fields.alt_label: Enterprises using RFID for product identification
fields.definition: RFID tags or transponders are devices that can be applied to or incorporated into a product or object and transmits data via radiowaves. The indicator includes their use for tracking of supply chain and inventory or for after-sales product identification.

fields.label: Enterprises with a formally defined ICT security policy
fields.alt_label: Enterprises with a formally defined ICT security policy

fields.label: Enterprises sharing electronic information on the supply chain
fields.definition: The indicator refers to sending/receiving all type of information on the supply chain (e.g. inventory levels, production plans, forecasts, progress of delivery) via computer networks or via websites, but excluding manually typed e-mail messages.
fields.note: Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector. Breaks in series because untill 2008 economic activities according to NACE Rev 1.1 and from 2009 data are based on NACE Rev.2. Since 2010 data include also sector 95.1-Repair of computers and communication equipment. Biennial indicator not collected in 2011.

fields.label: Enterprises that share internally electronic information on sales/purchases
fields.definition: Information on sales/purchases is shared electronically and automatically with the software used for any internal function as: the management of inventory levels, the accounting system, the production management or the distribution management.
fields.note: Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector. Breaks in series because until 2008 economic activities according to NACE Rev 1.1 and from 2009 data are based on NACE Rev.2. Since 2010 data include also sector S 95.1-Repair of computers and communication equipment.

fields.label: Enterprises using social media
fields.definition: Enterprises using at least one of the following social media: social networks, enterprise's blog or microblog, multimedia content sharing websites, wiki based knowledge sharing tools. Using social media means that the enterprise have a user profile, an account or a user license depending on the requirements and the type of the social media.

fields.label: Use two or more social media
fields.alt_label: Enterprises using two or more social media
fields.definition: Enterprises using two or more of the following social media: social networks, enterprise's blog or microblog, multimedia content sharing websites, wiki based knowledge sharing tools. Using social media means that the enterprise have a user profile, an account or a user license depending on the requirements and the type of the social media.

fields.label: Enterprises having a web site or homepage
fields.alt_label: Enterprises having a web site or homepage
fields.note: Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector. Breaks in series because until 2008 economic activities according to NACE Rev 1.1 and from 2009 data are based on NACE Rev.2. Since 2010 data include also sector S95.1-Repair of computers and communication equipment.

fields.label: Enterprises having a website with some sofisticated functionalities
fields.alt_label: Enterprises having a website with some sofisticated functionalities
fields.definition: Website having at least one of the following four functionalities : product catalogues or price lists (webacc), possibilities for visitors to customise or design the products (webctm), order tracking available online (webot) or personalised content in the website for regular/repeated visitors (webper).
fields.note: Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector. Breaks in series because until 2008 economic activities according to NACE Rev 1.1 and from 2009 data are based on NACE Rev.2. Since 2010 data include also sector S95.1-Repair of computers and communication equipment.

fields.label: Enterprises selling over 25% via a website or apps
fields.alt_label: Enterprises selling over 25% via a website or apps
fields.definition: The sales made via website or apps, during the previous calendar year, should represent at least 25% of the total turnover value (in monetary terms, excluding VAT).
fields.note: Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector. Breaks in series because until 2008 economic activities according to NACE Rev 1.1 and from 2009 data are based on NACE Rev.2. Since 2010 data include also sector S 95.1-Repair of computers and communication equipment.

fields.label: Enterprises selling over 50% via a website or apps
fields.alt_label: Enterprises selling over 50% via a website or apps
fields.definition: The sales made via website or apps, during the previous calendar year, should represent at least 50% of the total turnover value (in monetary terms, excluding VAT).
fields.note: Enterprises with 10 or more persons employed. All manufacturing and service sectors, excluding the financial sector. Breaks in series because until 2008 economic activities according to NACE Rev 1.1 and from 2009 data are based on NACE Rev.2. Since 2010 data include also sector S 95.1-Repair of computers and communication equipment.

fields.label: Digital Intensity score for Enterprises
fields.definition: The Digital Intensity score is based on counting how many out of 12 technologies are used by each enterprise. Then they are divided into four clusters of digital intensity: Very Low (scores 0-3), Low (score 4-6), High (score 7-9), Very High (score 10-12).
fields.note:
The 2015 list of technologies includes: usage of internet by a majority of the workers; access to ICT specialist skills; fixed broadband speed > 30 Mbps; mobile devices used by more than 20% of employed persons; has a website; has some sophisticated functions on the website; presence on social media; does e-sales for at least 1% of turnover; exploit the B2C opportunities of web sales; use an ERP software; use a CRM software; share electronically supply chain management information.
In 2016 the last 3 indicators have been replaced with: pay to advertise on the internet; purchase cloud computing advanced services; send eInvoices. There is thus a break in series with in general a reduction of the digital intensity scores.

fields.label: Employment of the ICT sector
fields.definition: Number of persons employed. In the System of National Accounts (SNA) this is defined as all persons, both employees and self-employed, engaged in some productive activity that falls within the production boundary of the SNA and that is undertaken by a resident institutional unit.

fields.label: Non-national European films in cinemas
fields.alt_label: Non-national European Films market share in EU cinemas

fields.label: Linear TV channels established in a Member State and targeting foreign countries
fields.alt_label: Linear TV channels targeting foreign countries
fields.note: page 125

fields.label: Video on Demand services available in the country but established in another EU country
fields.alt_label: VoD services available, established in another EU country
fields.definition: Video on demand (VoD) services (all genre except adult) available in a Member State, but established in another EU country

fields.label: Public Sector Information scoreboard
fields.definition: The PSI Scoreboard is a ‘crowdsourced’ tool to measure the status of Open Data and PSI re-use throughout the EU. It does NOT monitor government policies, but aims to assess the overall PSI re-use situation, which includes the open data community's activities.

fields.label: Computers for educational purposes
fields.definition: Computers used for educational purposes include desktop, laptop, netbook or tablet computer, whether or not connected to the internet

fields.label: Schools having a website
fields.definition: Own home page or web site available at school.

fields.label: Basic public services for citizens, which are fully available online
fields.definition: Percentage of public services for citizens out of a basket of 12 basic services (income taxes, job search, social security benefits, personal documents, car registration, building permissions, declaration to police, public libraries, certificates, enrolment in higher education, announcement of moving, health-related services) for which the entire procedure can be completed online
fields.note: Collected until 2010.

fields.label: Basic public services for enterprises, which are fully available online
fields.definition: Percentage of public services for enterprises out of a basket of 8 basic services (social contributions, corporate tax, VAT, company registration, statistical data, customs declaration, environment-related permits, public procurement) for which the entire procedure can be completed online
fields.note: Collected until 2010.

fields.label: Articles resulting from FP7 funded projects in ICT
fields.definition: Articles in journals reported through annual surveys of ongoing ICT research projects carried out by the European Commission - DG CONNECT. Outputs reported by participants have been validated in Elsevier’s Scopus databases by UNU-MERIT – Maastricht University under the service contract SMART 2011/0039 funded by the European Commission - DG CONNECT
fields.note: It covers FP7 ICT projects started before October 2013. The indicator is not expected to evolve regularly year by year, due to the coverage of thematic areas by calls which may differ from one year to another. Annual figures should therefore be interpreted with caution.

fields.label: Patents resulting from FP7 funded projects in ICT
fields.definition: Patents reported through annual surveys of ongoing ICT research projects carried out by the European Commission - DG CONNECT. Outputs reported by participants have been validated in EPO PATSTAT and Espacenet databases by UNU-MERIT – Maastricht University under the service contract SMART 2011/0039 funded by the European Commission - DG CONNECT
fields.note: It covers FP7 ICT projects started before October 2013. The indicator is not expected to evolve regularly year by year, due to the coverage of thematic areas by calls which may differ from one year to another. Annual figures should therefore be interpreted with caution.

fields.label: Publications resulting from FP7 funded projects in ICT
fields.definition:
Publications reported through annual surveys of ongoing ICT research projects carried out by the European Commission - DG CONNECT. Outputs reported by participants have been validated in Elsevier’s Scopus databases by UNU-MERIT – Maastricht University under the service contract SMART 2011/0039 funded by the European Commission - DG CONNECT. 
* It includes articles in journals and trade journals, conference proceedings, books, book series
fields.note: It covers FP7 ICT projects started before October 2013. The indicator is not expected to evolve regularly year by year, due to the coverage of thematic areas by calls which may differ from one year to another. Annual figures should therefore be interpreted with caution.

fields.label: Average EC funding per participation in FP7-ICT projects
fields.alt_label: FP7 Average EC funding per participation
fields.definition: EC funding is the funding committed by the European Commission through grant agreements signed during the reference year. The indicator measure the average EC funding attributed to each partner participation in a specific project.

fields.label: FP7 EC effective cofinancing rate
fields.definition: The cofinancing rate is the % of projects total costs which are covered by EC funding grants. Figures include all partners and third parties (as subcontractors).

fields.label: EC funding to participants in FP7-ICT projects
fields.definition: Value of European Commission funding committed through grant agreements signed, during the reference year, with participants in ICT research projects under the EU's Seventh Framework Programme (FP7). Projects under negotiation are not included.

fields.label: EC funding to private commercial organisations in FP7-ICT projects
fields.alt_label: EC funding to private commercial organisations in FP7-ICT projects
fields.definition: Value of European Commission funding committed through grant agreements signed, during the reference year, with private commercial organisations (SMEs and large enterprises) participating in ICT research projects under the EU's Seventh Framework Programme (FP7) - Cooperation and Capacities (e-infrastructures).

fields.label: EC funding granted to SMEs in FP7-ICT projects
fields.alt_label: EC funding to SMEs in FP7-ICT projects
fields.definition: Value of European Commission funding committed through grant agreements signed, during the reference year, with SMEs participating in ICT research projects under the EU's Seventh Framework Programme (FP7) - Cooperation and Capacities (e-infrastructures).

fields.label: Number of distinct organisations participating in FP7-ICT projects for the first time
fields.alt_label: Number of NEW organisations in FP7-ICT projects
fields.definition: The first call of FP7 ICT was in 2007 and all participants are considered as new ones. For each of the following years are counted only the organisations participating for the first time in FP7 ICT calls.

fields.label: Number of distinct organisations participating in FP7-ICT projects
fields.alt_label: Number of participants in FP7-ICT projects
fields.definition: Organisations participating in FP7 ICT calls for research projects (Cooperation and Capacities and e-infrastructures programs) during the reference year.

fields.label: Total number of participations in FP7-ICT projects
fields.definition: Each project has multiple partners participating and each partner can participate in multiple projects. For each participation there could be an EC funding (some participations do not receive EC funding). Third parties are included as partners, receiveing or not EU funding.
